title: Setting up a Django app on Heroku
description: This is a simple guide to setting up a Django project on Heroku.

children.value: This is a simple guide to setting up a Django project on Heroku.
The first step is to create a virutal environment in a new directory:

props.code:
$ mkdir proj && cd proj
$ virtualenv -p python3 .
$ source bin/activate
(proj) $ mkdir src
(proj) $ cd src
(proj) $ pip install django==1.10.5
(proj) $ django-admin.py startproject myproj .
(proj) $ ls
myproj        manage.py

children.value:
$ mkdir proj && cd proj
$ virtualenv -p python3 .
$ source bin/activate
(proj) $ mkdir src
(proj) $ cd src
(proj) $ pip install django==1.10.5
(proj) $ django-admin.py startproject myproj .
(proj) $ ls
myproj        manage.py
This sets up a virtual environment and creates an empty Django project. The next step is to create a settings module.

props.code:
(proj) $ cd myproj
(proj) $ mkdir settings && cd settings

children.value:
(proj) $ cd myproj
(proj) $ mkdir settings && cd settings
to settings to make it a python module.

props.className: language-python shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: Next we want to change the

props.code:
[...]
# Build paths inside the project like this: os.path.join(BASE_DIR, ...)
BASE_DIR = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))))
[...]
props.className: language-python shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: # Build paths inside the project like this: os.path.join(BASE_DIR, ...)
these three files will live in

props.code:
(proj) $ mv settings.py settings
(proj) $ cd settings
(proj) $ mv settings.py base.py
(proj) $ cp base.py local.py
(proj) $ cp base.py production.py

children.value:
(proj) $ mv settings.py settings
(proj) $ cd settings
(proj) $ mv settings.py base.py
(proj) $ cp base.py local.py
(proj) $ cp base.py production.py
Next we need to install PostgreSQL:

props.code:
(proj) $ pip install psycopg2
(proj) $ pip install gunicorn dj-database-url
(proj) $ pip install django-crispy-forms
(proj) $ pip install pillow

children.value:
(proj) $ pip install psycopg2
(proj) $ pip install gunicorn dj-database-url
(proj) $ pip install django-crispy-forms
(proj) $ pip install pillow
At this point we can check to see if everything installed correctly:

props.code:
(proj) $ pip freeze
appdirs==1.4.3
dj-database-url==0.4.2
Django==1.10.5
django-crispy-forms==1.6.1
gunicorn==19.7.1
olefile==0.44
packaging==16.8
Pillow==4.0.0
psycopg2==2.7.1
pyparsing==2.2.0
six==1.10.0

Before we push to Heroku we need to change a setting on Heroku related to static files:
Now we can finally push the git repository to Heroku:

There is a helpful guide on deploying Python and Django apps on Heroku's website
Here's an important excerpt regarding databases:

For Django applications, a Heroku Postgres hobby-dev database is automatically provisioned. This populates the DATABASE_URL environment variable.
No add-ons are automatically provisioned if a pure Python application is detected. If you need a SQL database for your app, add one explicitly:
So we need to run this command:
Next we need to access the terminal on our Heroku server:
Next we need to add database-related information to

props.className: language-python shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: Now we can push to Heroku:
Next we can run our migrations:

props.code: (proj) $ heroku run python manage.py migrate && heroku run python manage.py createsuperuser

children.value: (proj) $ heroku run python manage.py migrate && heroku run python manage.py createsuperuser
Now we should be able to login to the admin page with the account we just created, but CSS is still not working at this point. Here's how we configure static files to get CSS to work:
is needed so Heroku can run our static files.

Next we need to add the following item to the list of
components. This needs to be added to BOTH
in order for the local files to show on both our heroku site and the locally served site with

props.className: language-text shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: Next we have a few more items to add to our settings files:

props.code:
STATICFILES_DIRS = (
    os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "static"),
)

STATIC_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "live-static", "static-root")

STATICFILES_STORAGE = 'whitenoise.django.GzipManifestStaticFilesStorage'

#STATIC_ROOT = "/home/cfedeploy/webapps/cfehome_static_root/"

MEDIA_URL = "/media/"

MEDIA_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "live-static", "media-root")
props.className: language-python shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: And we also need to add some files to our base directory that will hold our static files:

props.code:
(proj) $ mkdir static
(proj) $ echo "body {color:#000;}" > static/main.css
(proj) $ mkdir live-static
(proj) $ mkdir live-static/static-root
(proj) $ mkdir live-static/media-root
(proj) $
(proj) $

children.value:

(proj) $ echo "body {color:#000;}" > static/main.css
(proj) $ mkdir live-static
(proj) $ mkdir live-static/static-root
(proj) $ mkdir live-static/media-root
(proj) $
(proj) $
And we also need to add the following to the end of

props.code:
[...]
STATIC_URL = '/static/'

STATICFILES_DIRS = (
    os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "static"),
)

STATIC_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "live-static", "static-root")

STATICFILES_STORAGE = 'whitenoise.django.GzipManifestStaticFilesStorage'

#STATIC_ROOT = "/home/cfedeploy/webapps/cfehome_static_root/"

so that it becomes tracked in git:
Next we can commit these changes and push to Heroku, and check to see if the static files are working in the admin panel. We also want to set

props.code:
(proj) $ git add --all
(proj) $ git commit -m "added static files"
(proj) $ git push heroku master
(proj) $ heroku config:set DISABLE_COLLECTSTATIC=0

children.value:
(proj) $ git add --all
(proj) $ git commit -m "added static files"
(proj) $ git push heroku master
(proj) $ heroku config:set DISABLE_COLLECTSTATIC=0
Now we should be able to see the admin panel with working CSS on both the live and local heroku sites.
Adding an app and configuring Bootstrap
Now that everything seems to be working we can start building our app.
Let's start by creating a new app:
will be the name of an app that we create here.
we can add a class-based view that will serve as the homepage:

props.className: language-python shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

props.code:
from django.conf.urls import url
from django.contrib import admin
from services.views import HomeView

urlpatterns = [
    url(r'^admin/', admin.site.urls),
    url(r'^$', HomeView.as_view(), name='home'),
]
props.className: language-python shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: Next we need to make some folders within our new

props.code:
(proj) $ mkdir page/templates && cd pages/templates
(proj) $ mkdir pages
(proj) $ touch home.html

children.value:
(proj) $ mkdir page/templates && cd pages/templates
(proj) $ mkdir pages
(proj) $ touch home.html
